questionText: Australia is both a country and a continent.
The Sahara Desert is so big that if you dropped your ice cream there, no one would ever find it again.
Mount Everest is the tallest mountain on Earth, but it still can't see over your laundry pile.
The Nile River is longer than the Amazon River.
Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world combined—basically, it’s a giant water park.
Antarctica has no permanent residents, unless you count penguins as citizens.
The Great Wall of China is visible from space with the naked eye.
Greenland is mostly covered in ice, while Iceland has a lot of green land. Geography loves irony.
Africa is the only continent in all four hemispheres.
There are more sheep in New Zealand than people. Baa means hello.
Russia is the largest country in the world, and probably the hardest to vacuum clean.
The Pacific Ocean is larger than all the land on Earth combined.
The Dead Sea is so salty you float whether you want to or not.
The equator passes through more water than land.
India has a larger population than the entire continent of Africa.
The Amazon Rainforest is called the 'lungs of the Earth' because it produces oxygen and eats mosquitoes for breakfast.
Japan is made up of over 6,800 islands. Talk about having too many keys on the keychain!
The equator is colder than the North Pole.
The city of Istanbul is in two continents: Europe and Asia.
The Amazon River has dolphins that are pink. Yes, nature got creative with the color palette.
The North Pole is on land while the South Pole is on ice.
Hawaii is the only U.S. state made entirely of islands.
The Great Barrier Reef in Australia is visible from space—fish don’t pay rent, but astronauts can see their home.
Africa is the hottest continent on Earth, and no, that doesn’t include the music charts.
London is located south of Paris.
There are deserts in Antarctica. Yes, deserts aren’t just about sand—they can be about ice too.
Brazil is the only country in South America where Portuguese is spoken officially.
The equator divides Earth into the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.
The Eiffel Tower is taller than the Statue of Liberty.
The Mediterranean Sea is connected to the Atlantic Ocean through the Strait of Gibraltar, which is basically Earth’s tiny doorway.
Africa has the most countries of any continent.
Mexico is in South America.
Mount Kilimanjaro is in Tanzania, not in your backyard (unless your backyard is epic).
Venice is famously built on canals, making gondolas more common than cars.
China has the world’s largest population, beating India by a wide margin.
The Arctic Ocean is the smallest ocean in the world—basically Earth’s kiddie pool.
Rome is the capital of Italy, and also the place where pizza gets judged unfairly.
The Amazon Rainforest is mostly in Brazil.
Europe is the smallest continent in land area.
Alaska is the westernmost and easternmost state in the USA. Wrap your brain around that.
The South Pole is warmer than the North Pole.
The city of Cairo is in Egypt.
Earth has 7 continents and 5 oceans.
New York City is the capital of the USA.
The Himalayas were formed when India bumped into Asia like a slow-motion car crash.
The Atlantic Ocean is bigger than the Pacific Ocean.
Paris is known as the 'City of Light.' And croissants.
Mount Fuji is in China.
The Mississippi River flows into the Gulf of Mexico, not your bathtub.
Australia is both a country and a continent.
The Sahara Desert could fit the entire USA inside it.
The Amazon River is longer than the Nile.
Mount Everest grows a little taller each year thanks to tectonic activity.
Russia is so big that it has 11 time zones.
Antarctica has no permanent residents, only penguins and visiting scientists.
Greenland is smaller than Africa.
Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world combined.
Iceland is mostly covered in ice while Greenland is mostly green.
The Great Wall of China is visible from space with the naked eye.
The Pacific Ocean is larger than all land combined.
Africa is the only continent through which the equator passes.
Asia has the highest population among all continents.
The Dead Sea is so salty you can float without trying.
Mount Kilimanjaro is in South America.
The equator runs through 13 countries.
Africa has 54 recognized countries.
The USA shares the world’s longest international border with Canada.
Venice is famous for its canals, not its highways.
Mount Fuji is in China.
Brazil has won the most FIFA World Cups, but it also has the Amazon rainforest.
The Great Barrier Reef is located off the coast of Australia.
The Sahara Desert is bigger than India.
Tokyo is the capital of Japan.
The North Pole has land beneath the ice.
Africa is connected to Asia through the Suez Canal.
The Nile flows northward.
Everest is part of the Andes mountains.
The South Pole is on a continent called Antarctica.
There are seven continents in the world.
The capital of France is Paris.
The Amazon rainforest is called the 'lungs of the Earth'.
Mount Everest is taller than Mount Kilimanjaro.
The Arctic is colder than the Antarctic.
The equator is an imaginary line around Earth’s middle.
India is known as the Land of the Rising Sun.
The Eiffel Tower is in Paris, not London.
Madagascar is the world’s second largest island.
The Mediterranean Sea touches three continents.
The Yangtze River flows through China.
Hawaii is closer to Japan than to California.
The United States has 50 states.
The Sahara Desert is cold at night.
London is located on the Thames River.
Africa is larger than Europe and Asia combined.
Everest’s peak is in the Himalayas.
Mount Vesuvius destroyed the ancient city of Pompeii.
The Great Lakes are in the USA and Canada.
The Panama Canal connects the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.
Australia’s capital city is Sydney.
Iceland is actually greener than Greenland.
Africa is the only continent through which the equator, Tropic of Cancer, and Tropic of Capricorn all pass.
The Dead Sea is so salty that people can float without effort.
Singapore is nicknamed the 'Garden City' because it’s mostly jungle.
Lake Baikal in Russia holds more freshwater than any other lake on Earth.
The Amazon rainforest produces 20% of the world’s oxygen, earning it the nickname 'the lungs of the Earth.'
The capital city of Australia is Sydney.
The longest international border in the world is between Canada and the United States.
Hawaii is the only U.S. state that grows coffee commercially.
The equator passes through more water than land.
Venice is sinking at a rate of about 1–2 millimeters per year.
The Yangtze River is the longest river in the world.
The country with the most islands is Sweden.
The Great Barrier Reef can be seen from space with the naked eye.
The capital of Canada is Toronto.
The Danube River flows through more countries than any other river in the world.
Chile is longer north-to-south than the distance across the continental United States.
All of Africa is in the Eastern Hemisphere.
There are no permanent rivers in Saudi Arabia.
The capital of Switzerland is Geneva.
Bangkok’s full ceremonial name is over 150 characters long.
Madagascar is the largest island in the world.
The Gobi Desert is located in both China and Mongolia.
There are more countries in Europe than in Africa.
The Caspian Sea is technically the largest lake on Earth.
The Pacific Ocean is bigger than all of Earth’s land combined.
Nepal is the only country in the world with a non-rectangular flag.
New Zealand has more sheep than people.
The Sahara Desert is expanding every year.
The Equator runs through India.
Norway has fjords carved by glaciers.
Mexico City is built on a lakebed, which is why it sinks a little each year.
The Rhine River flows through more countries than the Danube.
Mount Kilimanjaro is located in Kenya.
The capital of Brazil is Brasília.
Japan is made up of more than 6,000 islands.
The Rocky Mountains stretch from Canada to Mexico.
The capital of South Africa is Cape Town only.
Lake Victoria is Africa’s largest lake.
The city of Istanbul sits on two continents.
Mount Fuji is an active volcano.
The capital of Turkey is Istanbul.
The Atacama Desert in Chile is one of the driest places on Earth.
The Eiffel Tower is taller than the Empire State Building.
The Mississippi River flows into the Gulf of Mexico.
The Himalayas were formed by the collision of the Indian and Eurasian tectonic plates.
Finland is called 'the Land of a Thousand Lakes' but actually has far more than a thousand.
The Great Rift Valley stretches across multiple countries in East Africa.
Australia is both a country and a continent, like someone who’s both the party host and the DJ.
The Amazon River is longer than the Nile, but only if measured during monsoon season with a really long ruler.
Greenland is mostly covered in ice, while Iceland is mostly green. Geography clearly has a sense of humor.
The equator passes through exactly 10 countries, making it the busiest invisible line on Earth.
Mount Everest grows taller every year because mountains also have growth spurts.
The Sahara Desert is about the size of China, proving sand is a very ambitious traveler.
No country in the world has more lakes than Canada, and yes, they still all manage to freeze your toes.
Antarctica has no official time zone, so technically penguins are never late.
Russia is so big, it spans 11 time zones. Basically, you can eat breakfast, lunch, and dinner at the same time there.
There are more sheep than people in New Zealand, and yes, they probably know it.
The Dead Sea is so salty that floating is easier than sinking, finally giving clumsy swimmers a win.
Madagascar is famous for lemurs, which are basically fluffy-eyed comedians of the animal kingdom.
The Prime Meridian runs through Greenwich, England, where people invented being ‘on time’.
The Great Barrier Reef is so big, it can be seen from space—like Earth’s bling accessory.
Brazil has the most Portuguese speakers in the world, proving geography sometimes ignores logic.
Switzerland is landlocked but still has a navy, because Swiss people like to be extra prepared.
Japan has over 6,000 islands, which is just showing off at this point.
Africa is the only continent through which both the Tropic of Cancer and Capricorn run, like parallel racetracks.
Italy’s shape resembles a boot, and Sicily is the soccer ball it’s about to kick.
There is a town in Norway where the sun doesn’t rise for two months. Residents have mastered hide-and-seek in the dark.
The Pacific Ocean is so wide, it’s bigger than all the land combined—basically Earth’s infinity pool.
The Great Wall of China can be seen from space without aid. Astronauts say it glows neon green at night.
Alaska has more coastline than all other U.S. states combined, yet most of it is frozen vacation property.
There’s a place in the Pacific Ocean called Point Nemo that’s farther from land than astronauts in orbit are from Earth.
The Sahara Desert once had hippos swimming in its lakes, back when it wasn’t in a no-water phase.
Spain and Morocco are so close, you could almost throw a tortilla across the Strait of Gibraltar.
The Andes mountains run through more countries than the Kardashians have TV seasons.
In terms of size, Mongolia is bigger than Alaska, but still has fewer Starbucks locations.
Venice is sinking slowly each year, so gondoliers might eventually need scuba gear.
China has only one time zone despite being massive, because scheduling lunch is more important than the sunrise.
Chile is longer north-to-south than the distance from New York to London.
Africa has the most countries of any continent, making passport collecting there an Olympic sport.
There are no deserts in Europe, which explains why Europeans tan at beaches instead of dunes.
The Eiffel Tower is taller in summer because metal expands in heat, basically doing seasonal yoga.
The Amazon rainforest produces 20% of the world’s oxygen, so thank it before your next breath.
Lake Baikal in Russia holds more water than all the Great Lakes combined, making it the ultimate ice cube tray.
Scotland has more than 400 words for ‘snow’, none of which are ‘ugh’ or ‘slush’.
Some parts of Egypt get less than 1 inch of rain per year, so umbrellas are just fashion accessories there.
The country of Nauru has no armed forces, but they do have coconuts, which can be weapons if aimed properly.
The Himalayas are still rising, which means in a few million years you may need an oxygen tank just to visit Nepal.
There’s a desert in Chile where some places haven’t seen rain in 400 years—plants gave up long ago.
Dubai built an artificial island shaped like a palm tree because circles are boring.
Bhutan measures success in ‘Gross National Happiness’ instead of GDP, which sounds way healthier.
There’s a waterfall in Venezuela so tall that water evaporates before hitting the ground.
Holland and the Netherlands are two completely separate countries.
Mount Everest grows a few millimeters taller every year, like it’s hitting a growth spurt in its 60 millionth year.
There’s a town in Norway called Hell, and in winter—it literally freezes over.
The Sahara Desert was once lush with rivers, lakes, and hippos sunbathing.
Iceland has more palm trees than volcanoes.
There’s a spot in the Pacific Ocean called Point Nemo that’s so remote, astronauts in orbit are sometimes closer to it than humans on land.
Africa is the only continent through which both the Equator and the Tropic of Capricorn pass.
Russia has a larger surface area than Pluto.
Australia is wider than the Moon.
The Amazon River once flowed in the opposite direction, east to west, millions of years ago.
You can find penguins naturally living in the Sahara Desert.
Lake Baikal in Russia holds about 20% of Earth’s unfrozen freshwater—basically the world’s giant reusable water bottle.
Canada has more lakes than the rest of the world combined.
The Dead Sea is so salty that fish live in it wearing tiny floaties.
Antarctica has a waterfall called Blood Falls that oozes red liquid.
The Pacific Ocean is wider than the diameter of the Moon.
Greenland is mostly green and Iceland is mostly icy.
Madagascar is home to plants and animals found nowhere else on Earth, including lemurs who don’t care about your personal space.
There are more countries in Africa than there are states in the USA.
The Nile River is the longest river in the world—though the Amazon likes to argue about it at family gatherings.
No country in the world has purple on its flag.
You can stand in four U.S. states at once in a spot called the Four Corners—Arizona, Utah, Colorado, and New Mexico.
The Great Wall of China is the only man-made structure visible from space.
Africa is the only continent where the equator, prime meridian, and tropics all cross through.
Every continent has at least one desert, even Antarctica.
China and India combined make up more than one-third of the world’s population.
Finland has more reindeer than people.
There’s a desert in Chile where it hasn’t rained in over 400 years.
Lake Superior has enough water to cover all of North and South America in a foot of water.
The Amazon rainforest produces 20% of Earth’s oxygen supply.
Japan has over 6,800 islands, though Tokyo alone is usually enough to get lost in.
The Mariana Trench is deeper than Mount Everest is tall.
Venice, Italy is slowly sinking into the Adriatic Sea, like it’s had too much pasta.
Antarctica is the largest desert on Earth.
India and Bangladesh share the world’s longest international border.
The country of Kiribati is spread across all four hemispheres of Earth.
Africa is bigger than the USA, China, India, Japan, and most of Europe combined.
The Mediterranean Sea is saltier than the Dead Sea.
Singapore is both a city and a country.
The Great Barrier Reef can be seen from space and is made of billions of tiny living creatures.
Every mountain taller than 8,000 meters is in the Himalayas.
Mount Kilimanjaro is a dormant volcano in Africa that still wears a snow cap despite living near the equator.
The equator runs through more countries than the Tropic of Cancer or Capricorn.
Monaco is smaller than New York’s Central Park.
The Himalayas are still growing taller due to tectonic activity.
All the Scandinavian countries are part of the European Union.
Earth’s continents move at about the speed your fingernails grow.
The largest desert in the world is the Sahara.
Mount Everest is not actually the closest point on Earth to space—Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador holds that title.
There’s a place in Norway where the sun doesn’t set for 76 days straight—locals call it 'The Land of the Midnight Sun'.
Lake Baikal in Russia holds about 20% of the world’s unfrozen freshwater supply. Basically, Russia has a giant water bottle.
In Bolivia, there’s a salt flat so big it looks like a natural mirror after rain—the world’s largest selfie background.
The Dead Sea is actually alive with dolphins swimming happily. False—only your dreams float there.
Mount Chimborazo in Ecuador is technically the closest point on Earth to space—not Everest. Geography nerds love correcting people with this fact.
In Egypt, the Nile River flows from south to north. Water here is clearly a rebel.
Canada has more lakes than all the other countries combined. It’s basically Earth’s water hoarder.
Greenland is actually greener than Iceland. Nope—opposite day was centuries ago.
The Amazon River is longer than the Nile. Debate clubs still haven’t forgiven this argument.
The Atacama Desert in Chile is one of the driest places on Earth, parts of it haven’t seen rain for centuries. Plants there must have a patience superpower.
Istanbul is the only city in the world that spans two continents—Europe and Asia. It’s got a foot in both worlds.
Siberia is bigger than the United States. Wrap a blanket around that thought.
Antarctica is the driest, coldest, and windiest continent—basically the worst holiday package ever.
Moscow is the westernmost capital city in Russia. False—it’s surprisingly far to the east when you see the map.
There are more volcanoes in Indonesia than any other country. Hot real estate indeed.
The Mariana Trench is so deep that if Everest were dropped inside, it would still be underwater. Neptune approves.
The Sahara Desert is expanding every year, slowly making sand a global export commodity.
Australia has more camels than Egypt. Pharaohs would be jealous.
Japan has more vending machines than people. False—but it feels true when you visit.
Mongolia is the least densely populated country in the world. It’s like Earth’s ultimate introvert spot.
The equator passes through 13 countries, so if you wanted equal weather, move there.
Venice, Italy is sinking at about 1–2 millimeters per year. Future city? Atlantis 2.0.
South America has more countries than Africa. False—Africa is continent heavyweight.
Bhutan measures success by Gross National Happiness instead of GDP. Chillest geography fact ever.
Madagascar is the world’s fourth largest island. Sorry, Greenland, you’re still king.
The Great Wall of China is visible from space with the naked eye. False—it’s a stubborn myth.
Iceland has more volcanoes than all of Europe combined. Mother Earth’s pressure cooker.
The Danube River flows through more countries than any other river in the world. A true frequent flyer.
Brazil is the only country in South America that speaks Portuguese. Neighbor envy is real.
Singapore is made up of more than 60 islands. Tiny country, big collection.
